title: White House Pressed for NOAA to Disavow Forecasters’ Tweet Contradicting Trump
text:
WASHINGTON—President Trump told aides he wanted the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to “clarify” a tweet contradicting his claim that Hurricane Dorian likely posed a threat to Alabama, prompting his acting chief of staff to ask the Commerce Secretary to fix the situation, according to people familiar with the matter.

Acting chief of staff Mick Mulvaney ’s call to Commerce Secretary Wilbur Ross followed days of complaining by the president, the people said, and resulted in the scientific agency issuing a rare public criticism of its own forecasters.

Five days after Mr. Trump made his original claim about Alabama on Twitter, NOAA released an unsigned statement criticizing National Weather Service forecasters in Birmingham who had disputed and corrected the suggestion that Alabama was in the storm’s path.

Mr. Mulvaney’s call was first reported by the New York Times, and the president urging his staff to seek a new statement from NOAA was first reported by the Washington Post.

The National Weather Service is a part of NOAA, which is under the jurisdiction of the Commerce Department. A Commerce spokesman said Mr. Ross hadn’t threatened to fire any NOAA staff over forecasting and public statements about Hurricane Dorian, but declined to say whether the secretary had contacted NOAA on the matter.

Mr. Trump on Wednesday denied directing Mr. Mulvaney to disavow the forecasters who had contradicted his assertion about the threat to Alabama. “I never did that,” he said, speaking to reporters in the Oval Office.

The president first raised the notion of Hurricane Dorian hitting Alabama in a Sept. 1 tweet, where he said the state, along with three others, would “most likely be hit (much) harder than anticipated.” Soon afterward, the National Weather Service in Birmingham tweeted that Alabama would “NOT see any impacts” from the storm. In the following days, Mr. Trump continued to aggressively defend his assertion, including displaying a Sharpie-doctored map in the Oval Office that added Alabama to the path of the storm.

On Friday, NOAA released a statement calling the Birmingham forecaster’s tweet “inconsistent with probabilities from the best forecast products available at the time.”

Two days later, acting NOAA chief scientist Craig McLean said in an email to employees that he was investigating whether the agency’s response to Mr. Trump’s Alabama tweet constituted a violation of NOAA policies and ethics.

The head of the National Weather Service, Louis Uccellini, on Monday offered a robust defense of the Birmingham forecasters, saying they “did what any office would do.”

On Wednesday, the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology sent a letter to Mr. Ross requesting information related to NOAA’s actions in response to the president’s Alabama claim, including a reported directive to staff barring them from publicly contradicting Mr. Trump’s tweet and records of his reported threat to fire NOAA officials if they didn’t support the White House’s messaging.

“We are deeply disturbed by the politicization of NOAA’s weather forecast activities for the purpose of supporting incorrect statements by the president,” Rep. Eddie Bernice Johnson (D., Texas), the Science Committee chairwoman, and Rep. Mikie Sherrill (D., N.J.), chairwoman of an oversight subcommittee, wrote in the letter.

In their letter, the lawmakers also pointed to Mr. Ross’s own comments during his confirmation hearing in 2017. There, he was asked whether he supported a NOAA policy under which the agency’s scientists aren’t required to seek permission to publicly share their scientific expertise.

“I support the dissemination of valid information to the public,” he replied. “I don’t think that valid information should be concealed.”

Write to Catherine Lucey at catherine.lucey@wsj.com and Rebecca Ballhaus at Rebecca.Ballhaus@wsj.com
description: The White House pushed for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to walk back a tweet that contradicted President Trump’s claim that Hurricane Dorian likely posed a threat to Alabama.
